And they entered into the presence of Joseph, and he saw Benjamin his brother, and he knew him, and said unto them: 'Is this your youngest brother?' And they said unto him: 'It is he.' And he said: 'God be gracious to thee, my son!'
And he sent him into his house, and he brought out Simeon unto them, and he made a feast for them, and they presented to him the gifts which they had brought in their hands.
And they eat before him, and he gave them all a portion, but the portion of Benjamin was five times larger than the portion of any of them.
And they eat and drank and rose up and remained with their asses.

And Joseph devised a plan against them to know their thoughts, whether thoughts of peace were among them, and he said to the steward who was over his house: 'Fill their sacks with food, and return their money unto them into their vessels, and my cup, the silver cup out of which I drink, put it in the sack of the youngest, and send them away.'
And he did as Joseph had told him, and filled all their sacks for them with food and put their money in their sacks, and put the cup in Benjamin's sack.

And early in the morning they departed, and it came to pass that, when they had gone from thence, Joseph said unto the steward of his house: 'Pursue them, run and seize them, saying: "Why have ye requited evil for good? Ye have stolen from me the silver cup out of which my lord drinketh."' And bring back to me their youngest brother, and let him return quickly before I go forth to my seat of judgement.'
And he ran after them and seized them according to these words.

And they said unto him: 'God forbid that thy servants should do this thing, and steal any vessel from the house of thy lord, and the money also which we found in our sacks the first time, we thy servants brought back from the land of Canaan.'

'How then should we steal any vessel? Behold, here are we and our sacks; search, and wheresoever thou findest the cup in the sack of any man among us, let him be slain, and we and our asses will become servants unto thy lord.'
And he said unto them: 'Not so, the man with whom I find it, him only will I take as a servant, and ye shall go in peace unto your house.'
And as he was searching in their vessels, beginning with the eldest and ending with the youngest, it was found in Benjamin's sack.
And they rent their clothes, and laded their asses, and returned to the city, and came to the house of Joseph, and they all bowed themselves before him on their faces to the ground.

And Joseph said unto them: 'Ye have done evil.' And they said: 'What shall we say, or how shall we speak? our lord hath found out the iniquity of his servants; behold we are the servants of our lord, and our asses also.'
And Joseph said unto them: 'I also fear the Lord; as for you, go ye to your house in peace, but let your brother be my servant, for he hath done evil.'

And Judah drew nigh and said: 'O my lord, let thy servant, I pray thee, speak a word in my lord's ear; their mother bare two sons to our father, one is gone and is lost, and of him it was said that a wild beast had devoured him, and this one alone is left of his mother, and our father loveth him, and his life is bound up with this lad's life.'
'And it will come to pass, when we go to our father, and the lad is not with us, that he will die, and we shall bring down our father with sorrow unto death.'

'Now rather let me, thy servant, abide instead of the lad as a bondsman unto my lord, and let the lad go with his brethren, for I became surety for him at the hand of my father, and if I do not bring him back, let thy servant bear the blame before my father for ever.'
And Joseph saw that they were all of one mind for good, and he could not refrain himself, and he told them that he was Joseph.
And he conversed with them in the Hebrew tongue and fell on their necks and wept. But they knew him not, and they began to be afraid.
And he said unto them: 'Fear not, I am Joseph your brother, he whom ye sold into Egypt; God sent me before you to be a provider, that life might be preserved on the earth.'
'And behold the famine has been two years in the land, and there are yet five years without harvest or tree-planting or seed-time.'

'Now haste ye and go down to my father, and say unto him: "Thus saith Joseph thy son, God hath made me lord over all the land of Egypt; come down unto me and tarry not, and thou shalt dwell in the land of Goshen, and be near me, thou and thy sons and thy sons' sons, and thy sheep and thy cattle, and all that is thine; and I will provide for thee there; for there are yet five years of famine, lest thou and thy house and all that thou hast perish."'
And Joseph gave them chariots and food for the way, and he gave them all double changes of raiment, but to Benjamin he gave five changes of raiment and five hundred (pieces) of silver.
And he sent to his father ten asses which carried everything which was good in Egypt, and he sent them away.
And they went up and told their father that Joseph was alive, and was measuring out corn to all the nations of the earth, and that he was lord over all the land of Egypt.

And Jacob did not believe it, for he was as it were in a trance in his mind; but when he saw the chariots which Joseph had sent, his spirit revived, and he said: 'It is enough for me if Joseph is alive; I will go down and see him before I die.'

And Israel took his journey from the Well of the Oath on the new moon of the third month, and he came to the Well of the Oath, and he offered a sacrifice to the God of his father Isaac on the seventh of this month.
And Jacob remembered the dream which he had seen at Bethel, and he was afraid to go down into Egypt.

And he thought in his spirit of sending word to Joseph to come to him, and that he would not go down, but he remained there seven days to see if he should see a vision whether he should remain or go down.

And he celebrated the harvest festival of the first-fruits with old grain, for in all the land of Canaan there was not a handful of seed (to be found) in the land, for the famine was over all the beasts and cattle and birds, and over man.

And on the seventh of the month the Lord appeared unto him, and said unto him: 'Jacob, Jacob'; and he said: 'Here am I.' And He said unto him: 'I am the God of thy fathers, the God of Abraham and Isaac; fear not to go down into Egypt, for I will there make of thee a great nation.'
'I will go down with thee, and I will be thy guide, and I will bring thee up again in this land to be buried here, and Joseph shall put his hands upon thine eyes. Fear not, go down into Egypt.'
And his sons rose up, and his sons' sons, and they placed their father and their possessions on the wagons.
And Israel rose up from the Well of the Oath on the sixteenth of this third month, and he went to the land of Egypt.
And Israel sent Judah before him to his son Joseph, to examine the land of Goshen, for Joseph had told his brothers that they should come and dwell there, that they might be near him.
And this was the goodliest (land) in the land of Egypt, and near to him, for all (them) and also for (their) cattle.
And these are the names of the sons of Jacob who went into Egypt with Jacob their father.
Reuben, the first-born of Israel; and these are the names of his sons: Hanoch, and Pallu, and Hezron, and Carmi--five.
Simeon and his sons; and these are the names of his sons: Jemuel, and Jamin, and Ohad, and Jachin, and Zohar, and Shaul, the son of the Zephathite woman--seven.
Levi and his sons; and these are the names of his sons: Gershon, and Kohath, and Merari--four.
Judah and his sons; and these are the names of his sons: Shelah, and Perez, and Zerah--four.
Issachar and his sons; and these are the names of his sons: Tola, and Phua, and Jasub, and Shimron--five.
Zebulun and his sons; and these are the names of his sons: Sered, and Elon, and Jahleel--four.
And these are the sons of Leah and their sons who went into Egypt with their father Jacob, thirty-three.
And the sons of Zilpah, Leah's handmaid, the wife of Jacob, whom she bare to Jacob: Gad and Asher.
And these are the names of their sons who went into Egypt with him. The sons of Gad: Ziphion, and Haggi, and Shuni, and Ezbon, and Eri, and Areli, and Arodi--eight.
And the sons of Asher: Imnah, and Ishua, and Ishvi, and Beriah, and Serah their one sister--six.
All the souls (were) fourteen, and all those of Leah were forty-seven.
And the sons of Rachel, the wife of Jacob: Joseph and Benjamin.
And there were born to Joseph in Egypt before his father came into Egypt, those whom Asenath, daughter of Potipherah priest of Heliopolis, bare unto him, Manasseh and Ephraim--three.
And the sons of Benjamin: Bela, and Becher, and Ashbel, Gera, and Naaman, and Ehi, and Rosh, and Muppim, and Huppim, and Ard--eleven.
And all the souls of Rachel were fourteen.
And the sons of Bilhah, the handmaid of Rachel, the wife of Jacob, whom she bare to Jacob: Dan and Naphtali.
And these are the names of their sons who went into Egypt with them. The sons of Dan: Hushim, and Samon, and Asudi, and Iyaka, and Ishmael--six.
And they died in the year they entered into Egypt, and there was left to Dan Hushim alone.
And these are the names of the sons of Naphtali: Jahzeel, and Guni, and Jezer, and Shillem, and Iv.
And Iv, who was born after the years of famine, died in Egypt.
And all the souls of Rachel were twenty-six.
And all the souls of Jacob which went into Egypt were seventy souls. These are his children and his children's children, in all seventy; but five died in Egypt before Joseph, and had no children.

And in the land of Canaan two sons of Judah died, Er and Onan, and they had no children; and the children of Israel buried those who perished, and they were reckoned among the seventy Gentile nations.
And Israel went into the land of Egypt, into the land of Goshen, on the new moon of the fourth month, in the second year of the third week of the forty-fifth jubilee.
And Joseph went to meet his father Jacob, to the land of Goshen, and he fell on his father's neck and wept.

And Israel said unto Joseph: 'Now let me die, since I have seen thee, and now may the Lord God of Israel be blessed, the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac, who hath not withheld His mercy and His kindness from His servant Jacob.'
'It is enough for me that I have seen thy face while I am yet alive; yea, true is the vision which I saw at Bethel. Blessed be the Lord my God for ever and ever, and blessed be His name.'

And Joseph and his brothers ate bread before their father and drank wine, and Jacob rejoiced with exceeding great joy because he saw Joseph eating with his brothers and drinking before him, and he blessed the Creator of all things who had preserved him, and had preserved for him his twelve sons.
And Joseph had given to his father and to his brothers as a possession the best of the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen.

And Pharaoh loved Joseph, and gave to his father and his brothers a gift of the land of Goshen, that they might dwell therein; and Joseph provided for his father and his brothers and all their possessions with bread as much as sufficed them for the seven years of famine.

And the land of Egypt suffered by reason of the famine, and Joseph acquired all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh for food, and he got possession of their cattle and their money and their horses and their sheep, and he brought it all to Pharaoh.

And the years of famine were accomplished, and Joseph gave to the people who were in the land of Egypt seed and food, that they might sow (the land) in the eighth year, for the river had overflowed all the land of Egypt.

For during the seven years of famine it had not overflowed and had irrigated only a few places on the bank of the river, but now it overflowed and the Egyptians sowed the land, and it produced much corn that year.
And this was the first year of the fourth week of the forty-fifth jubilee.
And Joseph took of the corn of the harvest the fifth part for the king and left four parts for them for food and for seed, and Joseph made it an ordinance for the land of Egypt until this day.

And Israel dwelt in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen, seventeen years, and all the days which he lived were three jubilees, one hundred and forty-seven years; and he died in the fourth year of the fifth week of the forty-fifth jubilee.

And Israel blessed his sons before he died and told them everything that would befall them in the land of Egypt; and he made known to them what would come upon them in the last days, and blessed them and gave to Joseph two portions in the land.

And he fell asleep with his fathers, and he was buried in the double cave in the land of Canaan, near Abraham his father in the sepulchre which he digged for himself in the double cave in the land of Hebron.
And he gave all his books and the books of his fathers to Levi his son that he might preserve them and renew them for his children until this day.

And it came to pass that, after Jacob died, the children of Israel multiplied in the land of Egypt, and they became a great nation, and they were of one accord in heart, so that every one loved his brother and every man helped his brother, and they increased abundantly and multiplied exceedingly.

And ten weeks of years, all the days of the life of Joseph after his father Jacob, the King of Egypt died, and his sons rose up in his stead; and Joseph was in Egypt, and all his brothers and all the generation which went down with Jacob into Egypt.

And there was a war between the king of Egypt and the king of Canaan, and the children of Israel went forth with the king of Egypt, and their brothers were in the land of Canaan, and they fought with the king of Canaan and he fled, and they pursued him to the gates of Erech, and they took him captive.
And they slew his sons and the people of his land, and the king of Egypt returned in peace, and the children of Israel returned to the land of Egypt with him, and there was peace from that day forth.
And Joseph died in the fourth year of the sixth week of the forty-sixth jubilee; and they buried him in the land of Canaan, and all his brothers died after him.

And the king of Egypt went forth to war with the king of Canaan in the forty-seventh jubilee, in the second week in the second year thereof, and the children of Israel brought up the bones of all the sons of Jacob, save the bones of Joseph, and they buried them in the field in the double cave in the mountain.
And the most (of them) returned to Egypt, but a few of them remained in the mountain of Hebron, and Amram thy father remained with them.
And the king of Canaan was victorious over the king of Egypt, and he shut the gates of Egypt.

And he devised an evil device against the children of Israel of afflicting them; and he said unto the people of Egypt: 'Behold the people of the children of Israel have increased and multiplied more than we. Come and let us deal wisely with them before they become too many, and let us afflict them with slavery before war come upon us and before they also fight against us; else they will join themselves unto our enemies and get them up out of our land, for their hearts and faces are towards the land of Canaan.'

And he set over them taskmasters to afflict them with slavery; and they built strong cities for Pharaoh, Pithom and Raamses and they built all the walls and all the fortifications which had fallen in the cities of Egypt.
And they made them serve with rigour, and the more they evilly entreated them, the more they multiplied and increased.
And the people of Egypt abominated the children of Israel.

And in the seventh week, in the seventh year, in the forty-seventh jubilee, thy father went up from Egypt, and he took to himself a wife, and her name was Jochebed, the daughter of Levi, his father's sister, and she bare him a son in the fourth year of this week, and he called his name Aaron.
And in the fourth year of the eighth week, she bare thee, and thy father called thy name Moses.
And in those days Pharaoh, king of Egypt, gave a command regarding them, saying: 'Every male child that is born to the Hebrews, cast it into the river.'
And they cast them (in) for seven months until the day thou wast born. And thy mother hid thee for three months, and they told Pharaoh regarding her.

And she made an ark for thee, and covered it with pitch and asphalt, and placed it in the flags on the bank of the river, and she placed thee in it, and thy sister stood at a distance to see what would be done unto thee.
And at that time the daughter of Pharaoh came to the river to bathe, and she saw the ark and called her handmaidens and she opened it and found thee.
And she had compassion on thee, and thy sister said unto her: 'Shall I go and call for thee one of the Hebrew women to nurse and suckle this child for thee?' And she said: 'Go.'
And she went and called thy mother Jochebed, and she gave her wages, and she nursed thee.

And when thou wast grown, they brought thee to the daughter of Pharaoh, and thou becamest her son, and Amram thy father taught thee writing, and after thou hadst completed three weeks of years he brought thee into the royal court.

And thou wast in the court three weeks of years until the time when thou wentest forth from the royal court and sawest an Egyptian smiting thy companion who was of the children of Israel, and thou slewest him and hiddest him in the sand.
And on the next day thou foundest two of the children of Israel striving together, and thou saidst to him that did the wrong: 'Why smitest thou thy brother?'

And he was wroth and angry, and said: 'Who made thee a prince and a judge over us? Thinkest thou to slay me as thou slewest the Egyptian yesterday?' And thou wast afraid and fleddest on account of these words.

And in the sixth year of the third week of the forty-eighth jubilee, thou wentest and dwelt in the land of Midian five weeks of years and one year. And thou returnedst into Egypt in the second week in the second year in the fiftieth jubilee.
And thou thyself knowest what He spake unto thee on Mount Sinai, and what the prince Mastema desired to do unto thee when thou wast returning into Egypt [on the way at the place of the encampment].
Did he not with all his power seek to slay thee and deliver the Egyptians out of thy hand when he saw that thou wast sent to execute judgement and vengeance on the Egyptians?

And I delivered thee out of his hand, and thou didst perform the signs and wonders which thou wast sent to perform in Egypt against Pharaoh, and against all his house, and against his servants and his people.

And the Lord executed a great vengeance on them for Israel's sake, and smote them through the laying on of His hand with blood and frogs, lice and dog-flies, and malignant boils; and their cattle died; and (He sent) hail, wherewith He destroyed everything that grew for them; and locusts which devoured what had been left by the hail; and He sent darkness; and (finally) the first-born of men and animals were smitten.
And on all their idols the Lord executed vengeance and burned them with fire.
And everything was sent through thy hand, that thou shouldst declare (these things) before they were done, and thou spakest with the king of Egypt before all his servants and before his people.
And everything took place according to thy words; ten great and terrible judgements came upon the land of Egypt that thou mightest execute vengeance on it for Israel.
And the Lord did everything for Israel's sake, and according to His covenant, which He had ordained with Abraham that He would take vengeance on them according as they had enslaved them by force.
And the prince Mastema stood up against thee, and sought to cast thee into the hand of Pharaoh, and he helped the Egyptian magicians, and they stood up and wrought before thee.
The evils indeed we permitted them to work, but the remedies we did not allow to be wrought by their hands.
And the Lord smote them with malignant boils, and they were not able to stand, for we destroyed them so that they could not perform a single sign.

And notwithstanding all (these) signs and wonders the prince Mastema was not put to shame until he took courage and cried to the Egyptians to pursue after thee with all the powers of the Egyptians, with their chariots, and with their horses, and with all the hosts of the peoples of Egypt.

And I stood between the Egyptians and the Israelites, and we delivered the Israelites out of his hand, and out of the hand of his people, and the Lord brought them through the midst of the sea as if it were dry land.

And all the peoples whom he brought to pursue after Israel, the Lord our God cast them into the midst of the sea, into the depths of the abyss beneath the children of Israel, even as the people of Egypt had cast their children into the river He took vengeance on a million of them, and one thousand strong men were destroyed on account of one suckling whom they had cast into the river.

And on the fourteenth day and on the fifteenth and on the sixteenth and on the seventeenth and on the eighteenth the prince Mastema was bound and imprisoned behind the Israelites that he might not accuse them.
And on the nineteenth we let them loose that they might help the Egyptians and pursue the Israelites.
And he hardened their hearts and made them stubborn, and the device was devised by the Lord our God that He might smite the Egyptians and cast them into the sea.

And on the fourteenth we bound him that he might not accuse the children of Israel on the day when they asked the Egyptians for vessels and garments, vessels of gold, and vessels of silver, and vessels of bronze, in order to despoil the Egyptians in return for the bondage in which they had forced them to serve.
And we did not lead forth the children of Israel empty-handed.

Remember the commandment which the Lord commanded thee concerning the passover, that thou shouldst celebrate it in its season on the fourteenth of the first month, that thou shouldst kill it before it is evening, and that they should eat it by night on the evening of the fifteenth from the time of the setting of the sun.

For on this night--the beginning of the festival and the beginning of the joy--ye were eating the passover in Egypt, when all the powers of Mastema had been let loose to slay all the first-born in the land of Egypt, from the first-born of Pharaoh to the first-born of the captive maidservant in the mill, and to the cattle.

And this is the sign which the Lord gave them: Into every house on the lintels of which they saw the blood of a lamb of the first year, into (that) house they should not enter to slay, but should pass by (it), that all those should be saved who were in the house because the sign of the blood was on its lintels.

And the powers of the Lord did everything according as the Lord commanded them, and they passed by all the children of Israel, and the plague came not upon them to destroy (any) soul from amongst them of cattle, or man, or dog.
And the smiting was very sore in Egypt, and there was no house in Egypt where there was not one dead, and weeping and lamentation.

And all Israel was eating the flesh of the passover, and drinking the wine, and was lauding and blessing and giving thanks to the Lord God of their fathers, and was ready to go forth from under the yoke of Egypt, and from the evil bondage.

And remember thou this day all the days of thy life, and observe it from year to year all the days of thy life, once a year on its day, according to all the law which hath been ordained, and do not adjourn (it) from day to day, or from month to month.

For it is an eternal ordinance, and engraven on the heavenly tablets regarding all the children of Israel that they should observe it every year on its day once a year, throughout all their generations; and there is no limit of days, for this is ordained for ever.

And the man who is free from uncleanness, and doth not come to observe it on the occasion of its day, so as to bring an acceptable offering before the Lord on the day of its festival, and to eat and to drink before the Lord on the day of His festival, that man who is clean and close at hand shall be rooted out; for he hath not brought the offering of the Lord in its season, he shall bear the guilt upon himself.

Let the children of Israel come and observe the passover on the day of its fixed time, on the fourteenth day of the first month, between the evenings, from the third part of the day till the third part of the night, for two portions of the day are given to the light, and a third part to the evening.
This is that which the Lord commanded thee that thou shouldst observe it between the evenings.

And it shall not be slain in the daytime, in any part of the light, but in the part of the evening, and let them eat it at the time of the evening until the third part of the night, and whatever is left over of all its flesh from the third part of the night and onwards, let them burn it with fire.

And they shall not cook it with water, nor shall they eat it raw, but roast with fire: they shall eat it with care, its head with the inwards thereof and its feet they shall roast with fire, and not break a single bone of it; for of the children of Israel no bone shall be crushed.

For this reason the Lord commanded the children of Israel to observe the passover in the city of His sanctuary, and not to eat it in their gates, that the name of the Lord may be named over the sanctuary of the Lord.
And every one that hath come at its fixed time shall be holy, and shall eat the passover in the sanctuary of our God before the Lord from year to year.

And do thou command the children of Israel to observe the passover throughout their days, every year, once a year on the day of its fixed time, and it shall come for a memorial well-pleasing before the Lord, and no plague shall come upon them to slay or to smite (them) in that year in which they celebrate the passover in its season in every respect according to His commandment.
And they shall not eat it outside the sanctuary of the Lord, but before the sanctuary of the Lord, and all the people of the assembly of Israel shall celebrate it in its season.
And every man who hath come on its day shall eat it in the sanctuary of your God.
And after this law I made known to thee the days of the Sabbaths in the desert of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai.

And I spake unto thee concerning the Sabbaths of the land on Mount Sinai, and I spake unto thee concerning the jubilee years in the Sabbaths of years: but the year thereof have I not told thee until ye enter the land which ye shall possess.
And the land also shall keep its Sabbaths while they dwell upon it, and they shall know the jubilee year.

Wherefore I have ordained for thee the weeks of years and the years and the jubilees: there are forty-nine jubilees from the days of Adam until this day, and one week and two years: and there are yet forty years to come (for learning the commandments of the Lord), until they pass over into the land of Canaan, crossing the Jordan to the west.

And the jubilees shall pass by, until Israel is cleansed from all guilt of whoredom, and uncleanness, and pollution, and sin, and error, and dwelleth with all confidence in all the land, and there shall be no more a Satan or any evil one, and the land shall be clean from that time for evermore.
And behold the commandment regarding the Sabbaths--I have written (them) down for thee--and all the judgements of its laws.

Six days shalt thou labour, but on the seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord thy God. In it ye shall do no manner of work, ye and your sons, and your men-servants and your maid-servants, and all your cattle, and the sojourner also who is with you.

And the man who doeth any work on it shall die: whoever desecrateth that day, whoever lieth with (his) wife, or whoever saith he will do something on it, that he will set out on a journey thereon in regard to any buying or selling: and whoever draweth water thereon which he had not prepared for himself on the sixth day, and whoever taketh up any burden to carry it out of his tent or out of his house shall die.

Ye shall do no work whatever on the Sabbath day save what ye have prepared for yourselves on the sixth day, so as to eat, and drink, and rest, and keep Sabbath from all work on that day, and to bless the Lord your God, who hath given it to you for a feast day and a holy day, and a day of the holy kingdom for all Israel is this day among their days alway.

For great is the honour which the Lord hath given to Israel that they should eat and drink and be satisfied on this festival day, and rest thereon from all labour which belongs to the labour of the children of men save burning frankincense and bringing oblations and sacrifices before the Lord for days and for Sabbaths.

This work alone shall be done on the Sabbath days in the sanctuary of the Lord your God; that they may atone for Israel with sacrifice continually from day to day for a memorial well-pleasing before the Lord, and that He may receive them alway from day to day according as thou hast been commanded.

And every man who doeth any work, or goeth on a journey, or tilleth (his) farm, whether in his house or any other place, and whoever lighteth a fire, or rideth on any beast, or shippeth by sea on a ship, and whoever striketh or killeth anything, or slaughtereth a beast or a bird, or whoever catcheth an animal or a bird or a fish, or whoever fasteth or maketh war on the Sabbaths:

The man who doeth any of these things on the Sabbath shall die, so that the children of Israel shall observe the Sabbaths according to the commandments regarding the Sabbaths of the land, as it is written in the tablets, which He gave into my hands that I should write out for thee the laws of the seasons, and the seasons according to the division of their days.
